body:
> Also many modern christians make the mistake, mostly because they are told falsehoods and are raised in a very feminized society, that women will just naturally submit to a man who exhibits christ-like virtues, but nothing could be further from the truth. Women are rebellious by nature which is one of the many reasons God put her under the authority if her father first and then her husband. Of course, this line of thinking is extremely offensive even to modern christians or conservatives. The mere concept that women need to be under an authority is enough to send a congregation into foaming-at-the-mouth fits, yet this is what the bible teaches, whether we dislike hearing it or not.

You are basing this whole line of thinking on a one-liner from 1 Timothy, one of the most heretical books in the bible, which was composed as part of a slapfight between the catholic fathers and Marcionites and attributed to Paul to counter Marcion (because Paul was his favorite apostle). Somehow women became associated with Marcionism and gnosticism at some point in the second century, with Marcion possibly having been a woman named Marcellina, so the church decided that women are inherently more evil than men just to ruffle Marcion's feathes. It seems the early church was more concerned with winning against Marcion than defending the truth, and unfortunately they've had us fooled for thousands of years longer than they even intended. You would be absolutely appalled and disgusted if you heard of Deborah, Ruth, Mary Magdalene, or countless others. And you wouldn't like the gospels either, Jesus supports eunuchs and says we will be like the angels in the resurrection, almost certainly implying genderlessness.
body_html:
Also many modern christians make the mistake, mostly because they are told falsehoods and are raised in a very feminized society, that women will just naturally submit to a man who exhibits christ-like virtues, but nothing could be further from the truth. Of course, this line of thinking is extremely offensive even to modern christians or conservatives. The mere concept that women need to be under an authority is enough to send a congregation into foaming-at-the-mouth fits, yet this is what the bible teaches, whether we dislike hearing it or not.

You are basing this whole line of thinking on a one-liner from 1 Timothy, one of the most heretical books in the bible, which was composed as part of a slapfight between the catholic fathers and Marcionites and attributed to Paul to counter Marcion (because Paul was his favorite apostle). Somehow women became associated with Marcionism and gnosticism at some point in the second century, with Marcion possibly having been a woman named Marcellina, so the church decided that women are inherently more evil than men just to ruffle Marcion's feathes. It seems the early church was more concerned with winning against Marcion than defending the truth, and unfortunately they've had us fooled for thousands of years longer than they even intended. You would be absolutely appalled and disgusted if you heard of Deborah, Ruth, Mary Magdalene, or countless others. And you wouldn't like the gospels either, Jesus supports eunuchs and says we will be like the angels in the resurrection, almost certainly implying genderlessness.

parent.body:
Indeed I think respect and honor toward all people, unless they have proven the effort to be a waste of time, is a good thing.

As for biblical marriage, the fact that it leaves one in dislike does not change the fact. God did not create marriage as an egalitarian effort and there is no required "feedback loop of love and respect", though the presence of one is a good thing. God commands the wives of unbelievers to STILL submit in obedience toward their unbelieving husbands, and commands christian husbands to continue to care and provide for their unbelieving wives. The love of a husband and the submission of a wife is not dependent upon the "feedback" of their spouse but on the obedience and submission towards God. In this neither the husband nor wife has any excuse they can place on the other, but must take the mantle of obedience on themselves.

I don't say this with any malice, but modern christians place too much emphasis on the importance of romantic love in marriage when the bible calls for no such thing. It doesn't discount romantic love, but romance is not a requirement of marriage nor a requirement of loyalty, obedience, submission, provision or protection. Solomon had hundreds of wives and it is doubtful he was romantically involved with more than a handful of them. He loved them by providing for them, though it was likely he didn't remember most of their names and likely had little interaction with them beyond sex, yet romance is made to justify modern marriage rather than the other way around. If a woman doesn't feel like she is romantically loved enough many modern christians give her cart blanche to end the marriage.

Also many modern christians make the mistake, mostly because they are told falsehoods and are raised in a very feminized society, that women will just naturally submit to a man who exhibits christ-like virtues, but nothing could be further from the truth. Women are rebellious by nature which is one of the many reasons God put her under the authority if her father first and then her husband. Of course, this line of thinking is extremely offensive even to modern christians or conservatives. The mere concept that women need to be under an authority is enough to send a congregation into foaming-at-the-mouth fits, yet this is what the bible teaches, whether we dislike hearing it or not.

The love of a husband and the submission of a wife is not dependent upon the "feedback" of their spouse but on the obedience and submission towards God. In this neither the husband nor wife has any excuse they can place on the other, but must take the mantle of obedience on themselves.

I don't say this with any malice, but modern christians place too much emphasis on the importance of romantic love in marriage when the bible calls for no such thing. It doesn't discount romantic love, but romance is not a requirement of marriage nor a requirement of loyalty, obedience, submission, provision or protection. Solomon had hundreds of wives and it is doubtful he was romantically involved with more than a handful of them. He loved them by providing for them, though it was likely he didn't remember most of their names and likely had little interaction with them beyond sex, yet romance is made to justify modern marriage rather than the other way around. If a woman doesn't feel like she is romantically loved enough many modern christians give her cart blanche to end the marriage.

Also many modern christians make the mistake, mostly because they are told falsehoods and are raised in a very feminized society, that women will just naturally submit to a man who exhibits christ-like virtues, but nothing could be further from the truth. Women are rebellious by nature which is one of the many reasons God put her under the authority if her father first and then her husband. Of course, this line of thinking is extremely offensive even to modern christians or conservatives. The mere concept that women need to be under an authority is enough to send a congregation into foaming-at-the-mouth fits, yet this is what the bible teaches, whether we dislike hearing it or not.

guild.description:
Ask and answer questions.

Rules:

🤔 Posts must be questions. This is a community dedicated to Q&A discussion, so post titles must be in the form of a question.

⁉️ No loaded questions.

📬 No spamming. Spamming comments or posts is not allowed.

😀 Be civil. Be nice. Harassment, trolling, and disruptive behavior is not allowed. Basically, don’t be a jerk.

🥾 Breaking these rules will result in posts being kicked and possibly an exile.

📜 Follow Ruqqus ToS. This is a given.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

parent.body:

WAR.. Not to mention the vast majority of women don't have the necessary psychology to kill animals, which is the most essential thing for survival. You can see this on modern survival shows.... women fall short in absolutely every single metric, especially group cohesion, the most glaring flaw with women, inability to maintain or form effective hierarchy. 

Leaving livestock domestication up to women? Pff, they are more likely to get fucked by the animals than to dominate them. How about hunting, tracking and slaughtering an animal that weighs more than a human? Unlikely. 

Even if your perspective were true, you are arguing from a perspective that with modern effortless society already set up by the endless generational toil and suffering and innovation of men, and which is still sustained by overwhelmingly male labor ( actual jobs like farming, plumbing, fishing etc etc are all still basically male only jobs), that women are somehow "superior" under that framework.

parent.body:
From an individualist perspective, no. 

But we are indeed *living in a society* which runs counter in many ways to a sort of individualistic hedonism which everybody seems to want to pursue in the modern day. You do not have a tribe, or a society if you do not have a collectivization of male labour and male lives (for defence/war). In order to collectivize male labor and lives you need to give them access to breeding. 

If a tribe gives a man a wife, they can have his life of labour, or his life should it be so necessary. The idea that a woman's romantic or sexual pleasure is of higher value that a lifetime of labour or a life in the defence of a collective is laughable. In any case, if the majority of men are left out of the "breeding" of the tribe, then they are not part of the tribe and increasingly will have no desire to work for the tribe and especially not die for the tribe. They'd probably rather die to spite the tribe and watch it burn in that case. 

Monogamy and rigid family units have been the basis of all human societies which ascended beyond small tribal nomadic lifestyles. It's not a question of "Is it nice?" it's "Is it something worth doing for the maintenance of a society?".

In order to collectivize male labor and lives you need to give them access to breeding.

If a tribe gives a man a wife, they can have his life of labour, or his life should it be so necessary. The idea that a woman's romantic or sexual pleasure is of higher value that a lifetime of labour or a life in the defence of a collective is laughable. In any case, if the majority of men are left out of the "breeding" of the tribe, then they are not part of the tribe and increasingly will have no desire to work for the tribe and especially not die for the tribe. They'd probably rather die to spite the tribe and watch it burn in that case.

Monogamy and rigid family units have been the basis of all human societies which ascended beyond small tribal nomadic lifestyles. It's not a question of "Is it nice?" it's "Is it something worth doing for the maintenance of a society?".

body:
> a non color blind man can see colors just as well as a woman can

No, men legit have less cones and more rods. Male eyes are designed to sense motion more easily while female ones are made to see an aesthetically pleasing environment. The usual sacrifice men make in everything, they give up what's happy to become stronger and better at physical labor and war and sex. This is why women are so much better at coloring things, because men can't distinguish between similar shades.

> Women also have an easier time in school since it's built around them.

School was actually built for boys initially, girls are just more productive and attentive in general. Boys have trouble concentrating because their bodies are made to zone out into a rest state in anticipation of upcoming labor. A NORMAL boy is the same as a girl with severe ADHD from what I've seen. Brainpower takes up energy, and men can't afford to waste it when they're meant for physical tasks. Men have more trouble than women in independent pursuits as well.

Women just aren't expected to do anything so they don't because they don't have to, because they are valuable just for existing. Men have to perform OR ELSE. "For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

post.body:
x-posted from reddit by /u/swiet, not my post:

---

I made this post on another sub and someone told me it would be a good idea to post it here as well.

I always thought that sexism, be it misogyny or misandry, can be best understood through experience. I am transsexual, which means that I have experienced both being perceived as a woman and as a man by society. So here's my experience.

Background:

I'm ftm transsexual. I spent the first 18 years of my life as a girl/woman and these last 2 as a man.

My experiences as a woman:

The good:

Most people treated me very well and those who didn't mistreated me because I'm autistic, not because I was a girl. I was never made to feel bad whenever I asked for help and when I did people were happy to help me. Guys were happy to help with emotional issues particularly. They were always happy to be there for me if I needed to talk. Overall my mental health and well-being was taken more seriously. Additionally it was easier to make friends. It just seemed like others were more comfortable around me and felt safe to open up more around me.

The bad:

Nothing really. I never experienced misogyny ( and I grew up in yeehaw land). I wasn't exactly attractive so I never received sexual/romantic attention from guys be it positive or negative. When it came to other girls, there were a few that were shitty but I think this too would have been worse if I was attractive as they would see me as competition.

My experiences as a man:

The good:

Socially, nothing really improved. I hear some people say that men are taken more seriously, especially when it comes to the work place. But at my work men and women are treated the same. I am more confident now but that's because my gender dysphoria has lessoned considerably.

The bad:

I don't ask for help much anymore, especially when it comes to my mental health. Whenever I do ask for help, people are less enthusiastic about helping me. And I've also noticed that the quality of help I receive has decreased. I find that it's harder to talk to people. They just don't seem as comfortable around me anymore nor does it seem that they trust me nearly as much. it's hard to make friends compared to a couple of years ago. People just treat me neutrally and sometimes even negatively. I noticed strangers are more wary around me. Nothing like pulling their kids closer or clutching their purses tighter, but they stay farther away and don't make as much eye contact (not that I mind, but I'm sure many people would).

Final thoughts:

It was a very jarring experience. I went from being treated how a person should be treated (trusted, listened to, supported, etc.) To being treated like, well, a man. In my experience I've been treated far worse as a man. I by no means regret transitioning in any way, but I do wish that someone would have warned me about this.

Keep in mind, my experiences are my own. For some people it can be very different. Additionally, I've only been treated as a man for 2 years now. Maybe that "male privilege" I've been hearing about will kick in soon /s. Or maybe I'll just more and worse misandry, especially as I progress in my transition and become even more masculine.

Shared from r/LeftWingMaleAdvocates
post.body_html:
x-posted from reddit by /u/swiet, not my post:

I made this post on another sub and someone told me it would be a good idea to post it here as well.

I always thought that sexism, be it misogyny or misandry, can be best understood through experience. I am transsexual, which means that I have experienced both being perceived as a woman and as a man by society. So here's my experience.

Background:

I'm ftm transsexual. I spent the first 18 years of my life as a girl/woman and these last 2 as a man.

My experiences as a woman:

The good:

Most people treated me very well and those who didn't mistreated me because I'm autistic, not because I was a girl. I was never made to feel bad whenever I asked for help and when I did people were happy to help me. Guys were happy to help with emotional issues particularly. They were always happy to be there for me if I needed to talk. Overall my mental health and well-being was taken more seriously. Additionally it was easier to make friends. It just seemed like others were more comfortable around me and felt safe to open up more around me.

The bad:

Nothing really. I never experienced misogyny ( and I grew up in yeehaw land). I wasn't exactly attractive so I never received sexual/romantic attention from guys be it positive or negative. When it came to other girls, there were a few that were shitty but I think this too would have been worse if I was attractive as they would see me as competition.

My experiences as a man:

The good:

Socially, nothing really improved. I hear some people say that men are taken more seriously, especially when it comes to the work place. But at my work men and women are treated the same. I am more confident now but that's because my gender dysphoria has lessoned considerably.

The bad:

I don't ask for help much anymore, especially when it comes to my mental health. Whenever I do ask for help, people are less enthusiastic about helping me. And I've also noticed that the quality of help I receive has decreased. I find that it's harder to talk to people. They just don't seem as comfortable around me anymore nor does it seem that they trust me nearly as much. it's hard to make friends compared to a couple of years ago. People just treat me neutrally and sometimes even negatively. I noticed strangers are more wary around me. Nothing like pulling their kids closer or clutching their purses tighter, but they stay farther away and don't make as much eye contact (not that I mind, but I'm sure many people would).

Final thoughts:

It was a very jarring experience. I went from being treated how a person should be treated (trusted, listened to, supported, etc.) To being treated like, well, a man. In my experience I've been treated far worse as a man. I by no means regret transitioning in any way, but I do wish that someone would have warned me about this.

Keep in mind, my experiences are my own. For some people it can be very different. Additionally, I've only been treated as a man for 2 years now. Maybe that "male privilege" I've been hearing about will kick in soon /s. Or maybe I'll just more and worse misandry, especially as I progress in my transition and become even more masculine.

Shared from r/LeftWingMaleAdvocates

post.meta_title: Are women or men treated better by the system? A trans man's (biological woman) perspective : MensRights
post.title: What "male privilege" actually looks like
